body:
Hi Dr. Oyallon, 

it appears that our examples/documentation are ran on a CPU machine. In the code for the scattering inversion if the machine is a gpu we set the number of iterations to 500, and this allows us to reconstruct the image in a minute or two. [This notebook shows the output if you run it on a gpu. ](https://colab.research.google.com/drive/12C6hAN58zhQFQ0vv57AvPGeYGEJUYnK3?usp=sharing)

Either we need to start building our docs on GPU, or change the number of iterations to 500 no matter the machine (and this would possibly make the documentation take longer to build).

@edouardoyallon @anakin-datawalker 

I'm not sure what is the fix to to scattering disk. do you have an image of what is supposed to be shown there/whats the correct/expected output? 

It looks to be pretty similar to Joan Bruna's figure from their seminal Invariant Scattering Networks paper. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39755015/171216834-d8666d57-284a-449e-b300-c2283c5614d0.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39755015/171217732-f43cf1fc-b4c1-4102-b50f-b93a2ac3560c.png)

issue.title: Utilize .to(device) semantics in examples

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body:
We have many checks for `"cuda"`, and pass to gpu using `.cuda()` in our examples, but we could use `.to(device)` semantics and not have to worry about all that. 

This issue is related to the overarching project of fixing our examples. Please see issues, #817 , #812 and pull request #815 for related details.

body: It's good to see the issue is compute for the first example of the gallery - for the scattering disk, I think the two pictures are similar yet the visualizations are different (the disks seem different) - yet I thought one of the claim often done about the scattering is that it is stable to translations/small deformations - thus the disks should be nearly identical. For instance, taking the (globally averaged) scattering visualization of $(u_1,u_2)\to cos(w u_1)cos(w u_2)$ for $w\in \mathbb{R}$ doesn't give what I'd expect (seems the disks are rotated by pi/4 and there are some weird oscillations)

I see your concern. I think fixing the rotation being off by pi/4 should be easy enough, but fixing the oscillations maybe a bit hard.

I'll see what I can do in 30 minutes worth of time.

@edouardoyallon  @anakin-datawalker  This seems hard. It seems like the ordering might be different than what's shown in Bruna's paper. The oscillations are a bit confusing. Is the ordering of our coefficents different than Bruna's original presentation? 

[Here is my notebook.](https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1jacon162Xtg0PKapC07AGAPbCMupaXG7?usp=sharing) To get the angles to better match, I simply negate the angle. 

Here I plot the first order disk. The first image is my regeneration of the disk for first order, second image is Bruna's disk from the paper. I was able to get most of the angles to match, but there are differences. 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39755015/171493828-9615619b-62f1-48a9-a1a7-31a6c0ffbb15.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39755015/171493855-494284a1-2334-47b4-8caa-5d4e293de66e.png)

Here I plot the second order disk. The first image is my regeneration of the disk for second order, second image is Bruna's disk from the paper. I'm wondering if the spacing is too close. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39755015/171494914-9b928222-e34d-449e-a73b-bd854d0b4641.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39755015/171494858-487630fe-bcbe-4041-b3db-b7027b98e31a.png)

I tested out example recontruct_torch.py, [it fails](https://colab.research.google.com/drive/13HHEwMZvPL1VqyIhyZzcc_hedRTOjgJj?usp=sharing). 

I'll submit a pull request fixing it soon enough.

repository.name: kymatio

issue.body:
This pull request fixes an example from erroring out due to not detaching tensors from the computational graph before converting to numpy. 

This goes a small way of solving #817

issue.title: DOC Remove warning from sklearn example.

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body:
Dear Esteemed Colleagues,

please accept my State of the Art (SOTA) result on the "Kymatio Sklearn Digit Recognition Benchmark" Benchmark.

Love,
ScatteringSepoy

-------------------------------------------------------

To be much less trolly, this PR removes a warning thrown by sklearn about a lack of convergence, while keeping the same runtime and improving accuracy by about 1.5 percent. 

This goes a small way of solving #817 .

issue.title: DOC Fix 3d example failing import

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body:
The 3D example on dev fails an import due to the fact that we now use a class structure for the backend. This PR fixes this by importing instead the backend and calling compute integrals. 

[Currently in the process of running the full example on a google colab.](https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1FzK481GSptZijQrmjRuJV9GNJcdtgyku?usp=sharing) 

This goes a small way of solving #817 .

body:
Using 50 epochs in the script here are the results for 

J=2
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39755015/171545912-2f6fb73a-bdff-43f4-9045-a661b02ddd25.png)
J=4 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39755015/171546035-f7595417-6d00-48d9-b4da-e9e9c3aaff84.png)

OG image for comparison.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39755015/171546194-902b5786-9c3c-46d3-b5a0-d646cf73757d.png)


It takes about 3 minutes and 25 seconds to generate both. I suggest we remove J=4 and just use J=2 for the example. This will take 1 minute and 9 seconds. 

What do you think Dr. Oyallon?
the disks are however quite different .. 👎 might be difficult to fix

issue.title: DOC Invert scattering increase quality of image

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body:
This pull request increases the quality of the image produced by the sphinx documentation.

some results and wall clock timings using the `time` console command; 
Prior: 
```
Epoch 14, loss: 0.0010976835619658232
PSNR: 14.85dB for order 1 and J=2
real	0m10.457s
user	0m16.764s
sys	0m0.836s
```

![Figure_2_bad](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39755015/171974335-a5f32d7a-861a-49e4-bc2a-d5378a46fca9.png)

Now: 
```
Epoch 49, loss: 1.9380240701138973e-05
PSNR: 22.97dB for order 1 and J=2
real	0m14.745s
user	0m33.890s
sys	0m0.772s
```
![Figure_racoon_good](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39755015/171974339-bbc80c35-b9ef-4db9-9526-960ea494e224.png)

This goes a small way of solving https://github.com/kymatio/kymatio/issues/817 .

issue.title: Examples are not in CI

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body: Following offline discussion with @lostanlen. Since examples are not tested regularly, they *will* break (see #817, #801, #775) without us realizing it. We should aim to have the examples run at somewhat regularly so we can stay ahead of these things. This will probably include trimming down the examples to a smaller and easier maintainable set.

repository.name: kymatio
